title: How Elon Musk Damaged Twitter and Left It Worse Off
abstract: Mr. Musk swooped in and exposed Twitter’s lack of business and financial prospects. After criticizing the company’s weaknesses, he now wants to back out of buying it.
byline: By Kate Conger and Mike Isaac

multimedia.caption: The billionaire SpaceX owner and Tesla chief executive Elon Musk.
The billionaire SpaceX owner and Tesla chief executive Elon Musk.
The billionaire SpaceX owner and Tesla chief executive Elon Musk.

title: Relief Eludes Many Renters as Fed Raises Interest Rates
abstract: As the central bank sharply increases borrowing costs, it could lock would-be home buyers into rentals and keep a hot market under pressure.
byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Conor Dougherty

title: What Is Delaware’s Court of Chancery and Its Role in Elon Musk’s Twitter Deal?
abstract: If Twitter sues Mr. Musk to force a sale of the company, the case is likely to end up at a 230-year-old court in Delaware.

title: China’s Economy Stumbles in the Fog of Covid War
abstract: Even if the country avoids new lockdowns of big cities, question marks over the pandemic and policy direction are dogging efforts to revive growth.
byline: By Chris Buckley and Alexandra Stevenson

multimedia.caption: Nanjing Street, a popular tourist and shopping area in Shanghai, last month.

title: In a Time of Conflict, Ukraine Entrepreneurs Make War Their Business
abstract: From costume makers to consultants, fashion brands to uniform manufacturers, Ukrainian ventures have switched to producing goods to help wage war.

multimedia.caption: A company in Ukraine that made clothing for hotel and restaurant workers is now manufacturing Ukrainian military uniforms.

title: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
abstract: Several states run by Democrats are pushing for stiffer rules on the spread of false information, while Republican-run states are pushing for fewer rules.
byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Cecilia Kang

title: Airline Pilots Seek Big Raises, and Broader Changes
abstract: Pilots feel frustrated and overworked, issues that they say the air travel rebound has magnified by disrupting operations.

multimedia.caption: More than 1,500 Delta Air Lines pilots picketed across the country last month to raise awareness of their concerns.

title: Germany on Edge as Russian Gas Pipeline Goes Offline for Repair
abstract: Supplies via Nord Stream 1 dropped to zero as the pipeline began a 10-day maintenance period amid uncertainty over how long the shutdown would really last.

multimedia.caption: A Nord Stream 1 gas pipeline facility in Lubmin, Germany. A maintenance shutdown is scheduled to last 10 days.

title: Some Surprising Good News: Bookstores Are Booming and Becoming More Diverse
abstract: More than 300 bookstores have opened in the past couple of years — a revival that is meeting a demand for “real recommendations from real people.”
byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris

title: Advanced E.V. Batteries Move From Labs to Mass Production
abstract: Makers of batteries that could charge in a few minutes are setting up assembly lines, bringing the technology a big step closer to auto showrooms.

title: Largest-ever SPAC will return $4 billion to investors after failing to complete a deal.
abstract: The billionaire behind it, Bill Ackman, said he was “unable to consummate a transaction that both meets our investment criteria and is executable.”

multimedia.caption: Bill Ackman’s SPAC, Pershing Square Tontine Holdings, was sued last year over claims that it was an investment company and should therefore be regulated.

title: Gerald W. McEntee, Union Leader With Political Clout, Dies at 87
abstract: He made the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees an electoral force in a time of Republican hostility to organized labor.
org_facet: American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees

multimedia.caption: Gerald W. McEntee at a union national conference in Washington in 2007. “He began to use the union’s political power to exact things that in an earlier era the union might have turned to strikes to exact,” a labor historian said.

title: A Few Words From a Master Journalist
abstract: Francis X. Clines wrote thousands of lyrical, acutely observed articles for The New York Times. Here are excerpts from a few of them.

title: Restaurants Face an Extortion Threat: A Bad Rating on Google
abstract: Emails sent to dozens of restaurants, including those with Michelin stars, threaten a barrage of one-star reviews unless owners pay.

title: A global deal to tax large corporations is delayed a year.
abstract: The organization overseeing the negotiations pushed back the rollout of new rules, a move that is expected to postpone the agreement until 2024.

multimedia.caption: The Paris headquarters of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, which said negotiators needed more time to hash out the details of a global tax deal.

title: Francis X. Clines, Lyrical Writer for The Times, Dies at 84
abstract: He brought a literary sensibility to his widely admired work as a reporter, columnist and editorial writer, whether covering the streets of New York or the Troubles of Northern Ireland.

multimedia.caption: Francis X. Clines in 1982, when he was a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times during the Reagan administration.

title: Twitter’s stock falls further as doubts swirl over Elon Musk’s takeover.
abstract: Shares have lost a third of their value since April 25, when the company’s board accepted Mr. Musk’s offer.

title: Oil companies oppose a windfall tax in Britain despite record profits.
abstract: Oil and gas companies say charging them a 25 percent tax on profits could deter future investment at a critical time for Britain.

multimedia.caption: A Sainsbury's market in London. A windfall tax on oil and gas companies had been announced as a way to help support low-income households in Britain.

title: Suspect in Abe Shooting Held a ‘Grudge.’ Scrutiny Falls on a Church.
abstract: The Unification Church, with links to conservative political parties worldwide, said Monday that the mother of the man charged in Shinzo Abe’s death was a member.
byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

multimedia.caption: Tetsuya Yamagami, who was charged in the fatal shooting of Shinzo Abe on Friday in Nara, Japan.

title: Does Public Art Have an Afterlife?
abstract: Public artworks have the power to uplift a city. Sometimes they end up in a museum, but other times in a dumpster.

title: Why Musk May Be Stuck
abstract: Twitter is in a good position to sue under a legal doctrine called specific performance, which allows courts to force a transaction to be completed, even if one of the parties wants out.
byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross

multimedia.caption: Buyer’s remorse.

title: Security Forces in China Attack Protesters Seeking Frozen Funds
abstract: After a rare mass demonstration, bank depositors demanding their money back were beaten, kicked to the ground and dragged away in the city of Zhengzhou.
byline: By Zixu Wang and Austin Ramzy

multimedia.caption: Protesters in the central Chinese city of Zhengzhou. Photos and video of plainclothes security agents attacking them were shared on Chinese social media, stirring anger over the authorities’ brutal response.

title: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
abstract: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.

title: The Week in Business: A Rude Awakening for Start-Ups
abstract: Job growth remained strong last month. Company earnings season kicks off. And Elon Musk backs away from his deal for Twitter.

abstract: Most legal experts say Twitter has the upper hand. But Musk revels in brinkmanship.

title: The Last Days of Suburban Office Parks
abstract: With remote work and new norms, a concept that arose in postwar America is dying off. Emily Badger, who reported on the trend for The Upshot, shares more.

title: Campaigns make their final push in Japan, undeterred by Abe’s assassination.
abstract: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s longest serving prime minister, was shot while campaigning for a candidate for the Upper House of Parliament.
byline: By Hikari Hida and Ben Dooley

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan campaigning for Parliament on Saturday, with increased security, one day after the assassination of the former prime minister, Shinzo Abe.

title: Bill J. Allen, Alaska Businessman at the Center of Scandal, Dies at 85
abstract: He was one of the state’s most powerful figures, but his extensive corruption schemes brought him down — and took several politicians with him.

multimedia.caption: Bill J. Allen, leaving federal court in Anchorage, Alaska, in 2009. He sat at the intersection of Alaska’s vast oil industry and the equally vast political interests arrayed around it.

title: The Nice-Guy Lawyer for America’s Tabloid Villains
abstract: The sweet spot of Arthur Aidala’s law practice is a headline-grabbing defendant who is hated by many. Somehow, that doesn’t mean people hate him.

title: Amid the Summer Flying ‘Meltdown,’ Add Lost Luggage
abstract: Surging air travel demand and airport staffing shortages have made this a bedeviling season when it comes to missing luggage. Here’s what to know if your bag doesn’t arrive when you do.

abstract: Some of the largest companies in the U.S. have pledged to adopt climate-friendly agricultural techniques. But some farmers say they haven’t provided enough incentive.

title: Uniper, Germany’s largest gas importer, asks for government bailout.
abstract: Russian gas cutoffs are causing huge losses for the utility in the “middle double-digit million” euro area, Uniper’s chief executive said.
byline: By Stanley Reed and Melissa Eddy

multimedia.caption: Uniper, Germany’s largest importer of natural gas, formally asked the government for help, including a request that it take an equity stake in the company.

title: ‘A One-Hour Layover Is Not Enough Anymore’: A Flight Attendant’s Tips on Surviving Travel Now
abstract: In two decades of flying, things have never been as stressful as they are now, a cabin insider says. Here, her tips from 30,000 feet for avoiding airline chaos this summer.
